posts.body:
On This Day In History

October 21, 1943: The Provisional Government of Free India is formally established in Japanese-occupied Singapore.

October 21, 1944: The Battle of Leyte Gulf, the largest naval battle in history, starts between the United States and Australia against Japan. It is the first battle using organized kamikaze attacks.

October 21, 1944: The Nemmersdorf massacre of German Civilians and Allied POWs by the Red Army takes place.

October 21, 1944: Aachen falls to American forces, the first German city taken by the Allies.

On This Day In History

October 16th, 1384: Jadwiga is crowned King of Poland. Her older sister, Maria was also a woman king–Maria was king of Hungary and Croatia, though she had little official power. Jadwiga, however, was an incredibly effective ruler, and she remains one of the greatest rulers in Polish history.

posts.summary: Travel ad from Apartheid South Africa targetting tourists from the US South (1979)
posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Travel ad from Apartheid South Africa targetting tourists from the US South (1979)

Image description:

A page of an ad from a magazine, yellowed. On top it has five well dressed White people enjoyed a large meal in front of the ocean, framed by rifles and flanked by the flag of the Confederate States of America and the flag of the South African Republic (Transvaal Republic).

Within the text there is a smaller photograph of a port town, one of three lions, and a painting depicting the Battle of the Gwanga, Cape of Good Hope, June 8th, 1846 by H.Y.Martens.

Text is split into three columns reading as follows:

“C'mon home to Africa’s South”

So you want to go someplace interesting, someplace exotic, someplace sun-drenched warm and welcoming for your vacation this coming season (without spending a lot of money)…but at the same time you want to feel at home.

C'mon down south, to South Africa.

Let’s face it, the best part of any country just naturally has to be the south…and that’s as true in Africa as it is in the U.S.

Here’s another truth for you…South Africa is one country where the dollar still buys you the great life.

This is a land of contrasts. Where 24 million people, speaking over 50 different languages (with English as one official language), from as many different cultural backgrounds live side by side.

Take the sub-tropical city of Durban in the garden province of Natal, where surfers come to find the ultimate wave.

Imagine you’re one of the people in the main illustration of this advertisement, enjoying a champagne breakfast as the sun comes up over the Indian Ocean.

That’s leisure living, Natal style.

South Africa boasts a greater profusion of wild game and plant life than any other country (16 000 species of wild flowers in the Cape alone). And conservation isn’t just a subject for conversation at cocktail parties, it’s a magnificent realization.

South Africans spend a great deal of their time trail-hiking through stretches of wilderness where nature has been left to herself. Or living close to the real Africa in one of the many game parks, (where the African lion is King and dinner a sizzling steak on an open fire).

No matter how you travel; by train, by air, by automobile (with a trailer if you like).

No matter where you stay; in sophisticated hotels, mountain chalets or thatched cottages by the sea.

No matter what you do; play gold, or tennis, go hiking or fishing or game spotting, or steep yourself in a history that’s not so different from that of the United States (we also had a gold rush, and wild frontier towns).

No matter where you are in South Africa you’ll discover how it’s possible to live with all the comfort and civilisation of the 20th century…and still leave unspoilt the primeval splendour of a continent as old as time itself.

You’ve probably heard and read a great deal about South Africa during the past few years.

Now come and see the truth for yourself. It’s going to cost you a lot less to discover:

Our world in one country.

Text columns end.

There is a space designed to be cut out, saying “I want to come to your world in one country. Please send mem the detailed full colour brochure.” It has a space for name and address.

In large gold letters at the bottom reads “Welcome to $outh Africa, the dollars best friend.”

In small, black text at the bottom, it says “South African Tourist Corporation New York; Rockefeller Center, 610 Fifth Avenue, New York, N.Y. 10020. Los Angeles: Suite 721, 9465 Wilshire Boulevard, Beverly Hills, California 90212. Chicago: Post Office Box A 3967, Chicago, Illinois 60690. Toronto: Suite 1001, 20 Eglinton Avenue West, Toronto M4R 1K8”

End image description

Los Angeles: Suite 721, 9465 Wilshire Boulevard, Beverly Hills, California 90212. Chicago: Post Office Box A 3967, Chicago, Illinois 60690. Toronto: Suite 1001, 20 Eglinton Avenue West, Toronto M4R 1K8”

October 12th, 1492: Columbus’ first expedition makes landfall on Guanahani (now called San Salvador Island), where he meets people of the Lucayan branch of the Taíno.

October 12th, 1792: The first celebration of Columbus Day is put on the Tammany Hall, three hundred years later, in New York City.

On This Day In History

October 5th, 1945: Hollywood Bloody Friday. A six-month strike by over ten thousand members of the Conference of Studio Unions (representing such jobs as set carpenters, painters, cartoonists, and other crafts) turns violent when the clash with the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employees, who had been scabs. 25 people were injured.

posts.body:
On This Day In History

October 4th, 1951: Henrietta Lacks dies of cancer.

Henrietta Lacks’ cancer was the source of the HeLa cell line, the first immortalized human cell line. HeLa cells are incredibly important in scientific research around the world. However, they were taken and used without permission, and the cell line is now incredibly lucrative while Lacks’ family saw none of the profit.

posts.body:
On This Day In History

October 3rd, 1952: The United Kingdom officially becomes the world’s third nuclear power after testing a weapon in the Montebello Islands, Western Australia.

The Montebello Islands are now a park, though tourists are advised to limit visits to affected areas to a max of 1 hour per day. The area is also home to one of Australia’s best oil and natural gas drilling regions. The islands are also an important environment for several endangered species.

posts.summary:
Common Fallacies in Propaganda
 Part II
posts.body:
Common Fallacies in Propaganda
Part II

Some fallacies may be done by accident by someone who has not thought through their own ideas. Some are done on purpose, to persuade others of logically unsound principles. It can be a good idea to figure out which one it is when you see someone using a fallacy–a good idea is, unless you have a reason to believe they are lying on purpose, assume they are acting in good faith. As Hanlon’s Razor states

“never attribute to malice that which is adequately explained by stupidity.”

The following fallacies are ‘informal fallacies’–issues with argumentation and rhetoric, but not containing an internal flaw within the argument as stated. Their flaws typically involve applying the argument to the real world.

  1. Fallacies of relevance: when an argument is sound but misguided or misses the point.
  2. Argument from silence: drawing a conclusion based on a lack of evidence. This one is very common in historical analysis–arguing, for example, that because there are no great ruins in the northern part of North America, there were no sophisticated civilizations. The reality, of course, is that these civilizations (1) tended to use biodegradable materials for architecture and (2) had their buildings systemically destroyed by colonizing forces.
  3. Post hoc: (false cause: post hoc, ergo propter hoc; correlation does not equal causation). One thing appearing to cause another is sometimes correct and sometimes not, and without a large-sample data collection, it’s hard to tell when it is valid and when it isn’t. This is one of the reasons you need to be careful of your own sense of what seems reasonable–just because you noticed something that may be related to a second does not mean it’s true.
  4. Naturalistic fallacy: asserting that something is 'because it is good’. Typically, people will argue something is good because it is desirable, preferrable, or some other synonym for 'good’, so they aren’t actually advancing their argument. We still have not been convinced the thing is good!
  5. Appeal to nature: assuming natural things are good and unnatural are bad. When given a choice between two hypothetical compounds that are exactly the same in every way, people still preferred the one that was apparently “extracted from a plant” over the one that was “synthesized in a lab”. Logical thinking should have valued them the same.
  6. Ad hominem: Arguing by insulting someone’s character. There are times when it may be relevant–such as a documented history of dishonesty. Mostly it’s a technique for diverting and escalating the conversation. This one is commonly done by all people on every side of every argument–it’s inescapable. Do your best to not use it!
  7. Begging the question: Circular reasoning where your chain of logic requires the end conclusion to be true–so the only way to prove it is for it to have already been proven. This is common in religious argumentation. “X god is real because Y holy book says so. Y holy book is correct because it was written by X god.” There’s no part where the logic breaks down or fails to connect, it just won’t persuade anyone who isn’t already part of the religion.

posts.summary: Today, September 30th, is the annual Orange Shirt Day (National Day for Truth and Reconciliation). An observance day to promote...
posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Today, September 30th, is the annual Orange Shirt Day (National Day for Truth and Reconciliation). An observance day to promote awareness about the residential school system in Canada and the continuing effects of cultural genocide, people are encouraged to wear orange shirts and educate themselves on the history of residential schools.

I have some links below that are not hyperlinked, copy and paste into your browser to learn more.

CANADA
[orangeshirtday.org]
[legacyofhope.ca]
[https://indigenouspeoplesatlasofcanada.ca/article/history-of-residential-schools/]

UNITED STATES
[https://boardingschoolhealing.org/education/us-indian-boarding-school-history/]
[http://www.nativepartnership.org/site/PageServer?pagename=airc_hist_boardingschools]
[https://www.npr.org/sections/codeswitch/2021/08/28/1031398120/native-boarding-schools-repatriation-remains-carlisle]

AUSTRALIA
[https://aiatsis.gov.au/explore/stolen-generations]

NEW ZEALAND
[https://thespinoff.co.nz/atea/14-11-2017/our-stolen-generation-a-shameful-legacy/]
[https://interactive.aljazeera.com/aje/2017/quite-genocide/index.html]

SCANDANAVIA
[https://www.rcinet.ca/eye-on-the-arctic/2016/02/10/sami-abused-in-swedens-church-run-schools/]
[https://www.theglobeandmail.com/arts/awards-and-festivals/tiff/sami-blood-shines-spotlight-on-assimilation-of-indigenous-children-in-scandinavia/article31892290/]

A UN report [https://www.un.org/esa/socdev/unpfii/documents/IPS_Boarding_Schools.pdf] also mentions residential schools in the following countries that had the goal of prioritizing colonizing language, values, and practices. I’m looking for writing from or interviews with affected people to link.
-Peru
-Mexico
-Venezuela
-Colombia
-Brazil
-Russia
-Vietnam
-China
-India
-Malaysia
-Palestine
-Oman
-Iran
-Kenya
-Djibouti
-Eritrea
-Botswana
-Sierra Leone
-Ghana

On This Day In History

September 29th, 1901: Enrico Fermi, Italian-American physicist and Nobel Prize laureate, is born. He is perhaps best known for Fermi’s paradox, the paradox between the lack of evidence of alien life and high probability that alien life exists. There have been many theories attempting to resolve this paradox.

posts.body:
dailyhistoryposts:

Female Knights in Medieval History

While women have been fighting alongside men for all of history, they usually don’t get the same recognition as their counterparts. Here are some cases where women did get accepted into chivalric orders, though they typically got a separate title. Some of the women were combatants, and some were not (but non-combatant men have been accepted in chivalric orders for just as long!)

  1. Order of the Hatchet (12th century Spain)
    Orde de l'Atxa|Orden del Hacha was an entirely-female order created after women defended the Catalonian town of Tortosa from invaders. With most adult men off to war, the women fought with hatchets and other tools. Women of this order were given social and financial privileges, including tax exemptions.
  2. Order of Saint-John (12th century Malta)
    A military religious order, the Order of Saint-John had female soeurs hospitalières and male frères prêtres who had essentially the same role in the order.
  3. Teutonic Order (12th century Jerusalem)
    The Order of Brothers of the German House of Saint Mary in Jerusalem accepted women primarily as consorores and hospitallers, in charge of supportive and medical services. However, these women did follow men to war to perform battlefield medicine.
  4. Knights Templar (12th-14th century Jerusalem)
    The members of the Poor Fellow-Soldiers of Christ and of the Temple of Solomon admitted women for a number of roles. We know that when the final got around to writing down their rules, it included continuing the already standard practice of admitting women. Most Knights Templar were noncombatant, especially financiers.
  5. Order of the Garter (14th-15th century England)
    Dedicated to the patron saint of England, Saint George, the Most Noble Order of the Garter admitted women regularly, often due to blue blood. However, women without high birth were admitted as well.
  6. Order of the Ermine (14th and 15th century France)
    The L'Ordre de l'Hermine was directly inspired by the Order of the Garter and dedicated to upholding one’s personal honor. It openly admitted men and women of any social rank, including the only known instance in Medieval history of a woman serving as Officer of Arms. This woman, Katherine Potier, was titled “Espy Herault”.
  7. Order of the Blessed Virgin Mary (13th-16th century Italy)
    A unique order that took up arms to pacify cities in the fractured Italian states. It was centered in Bologna and would admit women as fighters called militissa (literally ‘female knight’).

I would like to reiterate, as this post gets popular in certain circles, that transphobes/TERFs/gencrits/bioessentialists are not welcome. No history for you.

There is space in the incredible breadth of all of human experience for women who dressed/acted like men because of patriarchal constraints and trans men. History is about understanding ourselves and those around us. If you cannot extend that understanding to trans people, you are learning the wrong lessons from history.

posts.body:
Common Fallacies in Propaganda

A fallacy is any form of reasoning that in invalid. They may be due to an internal bias, or they may be deliberately used for the sake of argument. Recognizing common fallacies when they are being used is an important part of critical thinking. Do not allow the person presenting evidence to guide your conclusion-making–this should be done by yourself.

First, always remember the fallacy fallacy. Just because something was argued with a fallacy does not mean the claim is therefore false–just this line of reasoning should be discarded. You should always do your own thinking.

Here is a description of other common fallacies.

  1. Affirming a disjunct (false exclusionary disjunct): Given a choice between two explanations, thinking one being true means the other must be false. In reality, they can both be true. Example: either the globe is warming or the winters are getting colder. In reality, climate change has led to both an overall increase in average temperatures and more intense winters.
  2. Argument to moderation: Assuming that a compromise between two positions is always correct and the best.
  3. Definist fallacy: Defining a term in a biased manner, such that it becomes difficult to argue due to the unusual definition. Pro-choice advocates would claim that pro-life advocates do this, and vice versa.
  4. Equivocation: Related to the above. Using a term with more than one meaning, and changing which one you mean depending on the situation. The proposed “Wall” between the United States and Mexico is sometimes an actual wall, sometimes a fence, and sometimes a metaphorical “Wall” that represents strict immigration polices. This allowed its proponents, like Donald Trump, to be able to take a hardline stance without building a literal wall.
  5. False dichotomy: Presenting only two options when there are more,“ either you’re with us or against us!”
  6. Incomplete comparison: Making a comparison to nothing, so the claim cannot be effectively argued against. Claiming, for example, that a certain breakfast results in better test scores–better than what? Other cereals? Things other than cereal? Just not eating?
  7. Apples and oranges: Comparing things that cannot be compared with validity. Always be suspicious of comparisons–the reason two things can be compared should be stated and valid by itself.
  8. Lump of labor fallacy: Arguing that there is a set amount of labor to be done in a certain economy. This is often done by anti-immigration proponents, arguing that they will displace jobs from natives, despite recurring economic evidence that this is not true.
  9. McNamara fallacy: Overly or only valuing things that can be easily quantified and described when making decisions. Things like emotions, relationships, life experiences all count. Attempting to avoid this fallacy is why many institutions of higher learning are shifting to holistic admission approaches over only using grades and test scores.
  10. Nirvana fallacy: Rejecting solutions because they aren’t perfect, even if they are better than the status quo. This is a common argument against receiving vaccines–because they are not totally perfect, people suggest they are totally worthless. The nirvana fallacy is related to the concept of false dichotomies.
  11. Slippery slope fallacy: Suggesting a small action will inevitably lead to more negative ones. You might have heard this one in homophobic and transphobic attacks, connecting increased acceptance of LGBTQ+ lifestyles as beginning a “slippery slope” to pedophilia and bestiality. However, all evidence suggests that this never happens. It is important to note that some slippery slopes are real–when making a slippery slope claim, you should always support it with evidence that it has occurred in the past. Unsubstantiated claims can be disregarded, but this one is not always a fallacy

Always remember that propaganda and misinformation do not need to lie–they can mislead you with facts just as well. Do not allow other people to guide your thinking, only let them present facts and decide for yourself on your conclusions.

  8. Lump of labor fallacy: Arguing that there is a set amount of labor to be done in a certain economy. This is often done by anti-immigration proponents, arguing that they will displace jobs from natives, despite recurring economic evidence that this is not true.
  9. McNamara fallacy: Overly or only valuing things that can be easily quantified and described when making decisions. Things like emotions, relationships, life experiences all count. Attempting to avoid this fallacy is why many institutions of higher learning are shifting to holistic admission approaches over only using grades and test scores.
  10. Nirvana fallacy: Rejecting solutions because they aren’t perfect, even if they are better than the status quo. This is a common argument against receiving vaccines–because they are not totally perfect, people suggest they are totally worthless. The nirvana fallacy is related to the concept of false dichotomies.
  11. Slippery slope fallacy: Suggesting a small action will inevitably lead to more negative ones. You might have heard this one in homophobic and transphobic attacks, connecting increased acceptance of LGBTQ+ lifestyles as beginning a “slippery slope” to pedophilia and bestiality. However, all evidence suggests that this never happens. It is important to note that some slippery slopes are real–when making a slippery slope claim, you should always support it with evidence that it has occurred in the past. Unsubstantiated claims can be disregarded, but this one is not always a fallacy

Always remember that propaganda and misinformation do not need to lie–they can mislead you with facts just as well. Do not allow other people to guide your thinking, only let them present facts and decide for yourself on your conclusions.

Common Fallacies in Propaganda

A fallacy is any form of reasoning that in invalid. They may be due to an internal bias, or they may be deliberately used for the sake of argument. Recognizing common fallacies when they are being used is an important part of critical thinking. Do not allow the person presenting evidence to guide your conclusion-making–this should be done by yourself.

First, always remember the fallacy fallacy. Just because something was argued with a fallacy does not mean the claim is therefore false–just this line of reasoning should be discarded. You should always do your own thinking.

Here is a description of other common fallacies.

  1. Affirming a disjunct (false exclusionary disjunct): Given a choice between two explanations, thinking one being true means the other must be false. In reality, they can both be true. Example: either the globe is warming or the winters are getting colder. In reality, climate change has led to both an overall increase in average temperatures and more intense winters.
  2. Argument to moderation: Assuming that a compromise between two positions is always correct and the best.
  3. Definist fallacy: Defining a term in a biased manner, such that it becomes difficult to argue due to the unusual definition. Pro-choice advocates would claim that pro-life advocates do this, and vice versa.
  4. Equivocation: Related to the above. Using a term with more than one meaning, and changing which one you mean depending on the situation. The proposed “Wall” between the United States and Mexico is sometimes an actual wall, sometimes a fence, and sometimes a metaphorical “Wall” that represents strict immigration polices. This allowed its proponents, like Donald Trump, to be able to take a hardline stance without building a literal wall.

posts.body:
On This Day In History

September 21st, 1909: Kwame Nkrumah is born. The first Prime Minister and President of Ghana, he was an influential freedom fighter, political theorist, and revolutionary.

Nkrumah helped lead Ghana to independence and political stability, but he was an authoritarian and was deposed in 1966 by the National Liberation Council.

posts.summary:
Common Cognitive Biases in Propaganda
Part II
posts.body:
Common Cognitive Biases in Propaganda
Part II

These are a list of social biases, biases about our perceptions of ourselves and others, and how groups make decisions.

  • Association fallacy: assuming someone has a certain quality they may not have. It may be assuming authority figures know about random topics (authority bias), or assuming a person has the traits of who they spend time with (halo effect).
  • Fundamental attribution error: the tendency to explain your own actions by environmental factors and others by personality factors. For example, if you cut someone off when driving, it’s because you’re late and in a hurry. If someone cuts you off, it’s because they’re a bad driver.
  • Just-world fallacy: believing the world is fundamentally just, so good things happen to good people and bad things happen to bad people. This allows people to think that people who have had bad things happen to them must have deserved it, or even caused it themselves. Fighting the just-world fallacy is an important goal in disabled activism.
  • Puritanical bias: attributing a negative action by an individual to their moral character or personality when it could better be explained by broader social determinants.
  • Groupthink: when a group of people, trying to minimize conflict within the group, arrive at an irrational or dysfunctional consensus. Sometimes, the group consensus can end up being more extreme than the thoughts of any individual member due to the related concept of groupshift.
  • Outgroup homogeneity bias: seeing people not in your in-group as more similar to each other, and people in your in-group as more varied and diverse.
  • Reactive devaluation: devaluing a good proposal because it came from an enemy or opponent.


To learn more about other biases and fallacies, check out this video by Hank Green on SciShow. The name is bait, the video is pro-vaccination. It was made before the COVID-19 pandemic, and so does not make reference to it.

posts.body:
Common Cognitive Biases in Propaganda

Successful propaganda relies on a few logical and psychological tricks. They can never be completely overcome, but being aware of them in yourself can help you realize when you are being manipulated.

A cognitive bias is a pattern of thought that leads to irrational judgement. There are many, many biases. Here are a few of the most common ones.

  • Apophenia: perceiving connections that don’t exist. This could be overemphasizing a small sample size or a single story over large amounts of data of perceiving a relationship between unrelated events. Check out these Spurious Correlations! You may have fallen victim to apophenia in the gambler’s fallacy–feeling confident that a commonly occurring event will occur less commonly in the future.
  • Availability bias: overestimating the chance something will occur because its easily available to your memory. This might include anthropomorphism–thinking about non-human things through a lens of human actions, the frequency illusion (when you buy a blue Honda, suddenly it seems like every car on the street is a blue Honda! In reality, you’re just paying more attention). Survivorship bias (things that did not make it to the end are not included in the statistics).
  • Confirmation bias: THE BIG ONE. YES, YOU DO THIS ONE TOO. The tendency to seek out and more readily believe information that confirms rather than challenges your preexisting biases and preconceptions. A person presented with incontrovertible evidence they are wrong will often double down in support of the thing they were wrong about. Confirmation bias is one of the reasons the eyewitness testimony is actually not very reliable!
  • Extension neglect: the mathematical sin of ignoring the sample size. There is a mathematical way to determine if a group is able to generalize to the larger population, and some studies and many stories do not meet the threshold. A common way this manifests is by overestimating medical events. A medication doubling your risk of a side effect sounds scary, but not if your base rate was one-in-ten-million (now doubled to one-in-five-million). “One death is a tragedy, one million is a statistic” (the difficultly of judging large amounts of damage in proportion) is also a form of extension neglect.
  • Framing effect: Different ways to portray the same information can lead to different conclusions. Prefering default options over better changes, the tendency to spend more money in smaller amounts (like coins over bills), or viewing the benefits of something compared to a previous option instead of on its own merit.
  • Prospect theory: Problems in how we view future probabilities. This might include the sunk cost fallacy (not wanting to give up something bad because you’ve invested time or money into it), the psuedocertainty effect (being more likely to take risks to avoid negative outcomes than gain positive ones), and the tendency to prefer and actively defend the status quo even over change for the better.
  • Problems with self-assessment: People are very bad at self-assessment. Consider the Dunning-Kruger effect (unskilled people overestimate their ability, experts underestimate their ability), the illusion of explanatory depth (overestimating your knowledge of a subject). This also includes empathy gaps, places where empathy is reduced. For example, in the hot-cold empathy gap, people currently feeling strong drivers or emotions (hunger, madly in love, physical pain, extreme anger) have difficulty imagining not being in that state. People who are calm have difficulty imagining themselves subject to those drivers. So people in a ‘hot’ state act according to their drives and short-term goals, and people in a 'cold’ state are unprepared for when they find those drives triggered.
  • Truthiness: Believing something because if feels true. People tend to believe things that are easier to understand or if they have been stated multiple times. Consider people deliberately going down TikTok algorithms–they start to agree with statements they were originally opposed to because they heard it so many times. People also are likely to believe things that can be distilled down into simple, easy to remember catchphrases, especially if they rhyme.

  • Availability bias: overestimating the chance something will occur because its easily available to your memory. This might include anthropomorphism–thinking about non-human things through a lens of human actions, the frequency illusion (when you buy a blue Honda, suddenly it seems like every car on the street is a blue Honda! In reality, you’re just paying more attention). Survivorship bias (things that did not make it to the end are not included in the statistics).
  • Confirmation bias: THE BIG ONE. YES, YOU DO THIS ONE TOO. The tendency to seek out and more readily believe information that confirms rather than challenges your preexisting biases and preconceptions. A person presented with incontrovertible evidence they are wrong will often double down in support of the thing they were wrong about. Confirmation bias is one of the reasons the eyewitness testimony is actually not very reliable!
  • Extension neglect: the mathematical sin of ignoring the sample size. There is a mathematical way to determine if a group is able to generalize to the larger population, and some studies and many stories do not meet the threshold. A common way this manifests is by overestimating medical events. A medication doubling your risk of a side effect sounds scary, but not if your base rate was one-in-ten-million (now doubled to one-in-five-million). “One death is a tragedy, one million is a statistic” (the difficultly of judging large amounts of damage in proportion) is also a form of extension neglect.
  • Framing effect: Different ways to portray the same information can lead to different conclusions. Prefering default options over better changes, the tendency to spend more money in smaller amounts (like coins over bills), or viewing the benefits of something compared to a previous option instead of on its own merit.
  • Prospect theory: Problems in how we view future probabilities. This might include the sunk cost fallacy (not wanting to give up something bad because you’ve invested time or money into it), the psuedocertainty effect (being more likely to take risks to avoid negative outcomes than gain positive ones), and the tendency to prefer and actively defend the status quo even over change for the better.
  • Problems with self-assessment: People are very bad at self-assessment. Consider the Dunning-Kruger effect (unskilled people overestimate their ability, experts underestimate their ability), the illusion of explanatory depth (overestimating your knowledge of a subject). This also includes empathy gaps, places where empathy is reduced. For example, in the hot-cold empathy gap, people currently feeling strong drivers or emotions (hunger, madly in love, physical pain, extreme anger) have difficulty imagining not being in that state. People who are calm have difficulty imagining themselves subject to those drivers. So people in a ‘hot’ state act according to their drives and short-term goals, and people in a 'cold’ state are unprepared for when they find those drives triggered.
  • Truthiness: Believing something because if feels true. People tend to believe things that are easier to understand or if they have been stated multiple times. Consider people deliberately going down TikTok algorithms–they start to agree with statements they were originally opposed to because they heard it so many times. People also are likely to believe things that can be distilled down into simple, easy to remember catchphrases, especially if they rhyme.
